body.raw:
{
   "task":"diagnosisReport",
   "medical_text":"Diagnosis:
Primary Diagnosis: Chronic Kidney Disease NOS
Document Type: Discharge Summary
Discharge Summary:
•	Admission Date: 2024-01-04
•	Discharge Date: 2024-01-19
•	Date of Birth: 1932-02-29
•	Sex: Female
•	Service: Medicine
Allergies:
•	Nevirapine
•	Abacavir
•	Ampicillin
•	Tylenol
•	Zidovudine
Attending Physician:  Dr. Sarah Mitchell
Chief Complaint: Increased lower extremity swelling and concerns about self-care at home.
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedures:
•	Left femoral central line
•	Right internal jugular central line
•	Continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH)
History of Present Illness:
The patient is has HIV/AIDS (CD4 count of 5 as of 2023-08-23, unknown viral load) and cardiomyopathy (ejection fraction [EF] 20%) who was recently hospitalized for bibasilar pneumonia. She completed a two-week course of antibiotics (Levofloxacin and Flagyl). She presented with complaints of persistent leg swelling and weakness for two weeks. She denied shortness of breath, eating salty foods, and fever but reported consuming canned chicken noodle soup. She had received partial prescriptions after her previous discharge but did not know the names or doses of her HIV medications, identifying only Bactrim as her HIV medicine.
In the Emergency Department (ED), the patient received IV Lasix, and a femoral line was placed due to difficult venous access.

Past Medical History:
•	HIV/AIDS: History of PCP x 2, MAC, cervical dysplasia, HSV anal ulcers. Last CD4 count of 5 on 2023-08-19.
•	Cardiomyopathy: EF 20% as of 2023-12-28.
•	Renal Insufficiency: New renal insufficiency since 2023-11-18 with baseline creatinine in the mid-2s.
•	Depression
•	Asthma

Social History:
•	Divorced, lives with her 13-year-old daughter.
•	Ambulates with a walker.
•	Denies tobacco, alcohol, or drug use.
Family History:
•	Coronary Artery Disease: Mother died at age 57 from myocardial infarction.

Physical Examination on Admission:
•	Vitals: Temp 97.7°F, BP 112/68, RR 18, O2 saturation not initially checked.
•	General: Alert, quiet, pleasant, sitting in bed.
•	Cardiovascular: Tachycardia, S1S2 with S3, no murmurs.
•	Pulmonary: Clear to auscultation, decreased breath sounds at lung bases.
•	Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, non-distended.
•	Extremities: Pitting edema, femoral line in place with sanguineous drainage on the dressing.

Pertinent Labs and Imaging:
•	BNP: 64,499
•	Digoxin level: 0.8
•	Creatinine: 2.1 (slightly improved from baseline)
•	Hematocrit: 27.5%
•	Albumin: 2.2
•	CXR: Persistent bibasilar pneumonia with bilateral effusions
•	Echocardiogram: EF 20%, small-moderate pericardial effusion, global hypokinesis (2023-12-28)
Hospital Course:
Ms. Emily Carter was admitted for further management of her multiple conditions, including HIV/AIDS, cardiomyopathy, and renal insufficiency. She initially presented with concerns about increased lower extremity edema, but her physical examination revealed no significant change. She was started on IV antibiotics and transferred to the ICU after developing severe lactic acidosis believed to be secondary to her HIV medications (Zidovudine). She required continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH) for acidosis and D10 for hypoglycemia.
Despite treatment, the patient experienced multi-system organ failure, including liver failure, increased oliguria, pancreatitis, and hemolysis. After discussions with her family, the decision was made to discontinue dialysis and transition to hospice care.
Family Meeting and Transition to Hospice:
The patient's family, including her 13-year-old daughter, was informed of her prognosis. The patient expressed a desire to go to hospice, which was arranged. She was discharged on a course of antibiotics and continued medications for symptom management.
Discharge Medications:
1.	Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole 80-400 mg Tablet: Take 1 tablet daily.
2.	Sevelamer 400 mg Tablet: Take 2 tablets three times daily.
3.	Digoxin 125 mcg Tablet: Take 1 tablet every other day.
4.	Ipratropium Bromide 0.02% Solution: Nebulize every 6 hours as needed for shortness of breath.
5.	Pantoprazole 40 mg Tablet: Take 1 tablet daily.
6.	Lasix 40 mg Tablet: Take 1 tablet daily as needed for shortness of breath or painful edema.
7.	Cefpodoxime 200 mg Tablet: Take 1 tablet every 12 hours for 4 days.
8.	Azithromycin 250 mg Tablet: Take 1 tablet daily for 4 days.
Discharge Disposition: The patient was transferred to Rosewood Hospice Care.
Discharge Diagnosis:
1.	HIV/AIDS
2.	Cardiomyopathy (EF 20%)
3.	New renal insufficiency (baseline creatinine mid-2s)
4.	Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
5.	Asthma
6.	Depression
Discharge Condition: Stable
Discharge Instructions:
The patient is being transferred to hospice care, with goals of comfort and symptom management. No further labs, IVs, or fingersticks will be performed.
Follow-up: None required.
Physician: Dr. Sarah Mitchell
Facility: Rosewood Hospice Care
Date of Completion: 2024-01-18",
   "user_profile":{
      "gender":"female",
      "birthday":"1932-02-29",
      "martialStatus":"single",
      "religion":"Protestant",
      "allergies":[
         "Nevirapine",
         "Abacavir",
         "Ampicillin",
         "Tylenol",
         "Zidovudine"
      ],
      "educationalBackground":"school",
      "professionalBackground":"technical",
      "languagePreferences":[
         "avoidAbstractTerms"
      ]
   }
}

   "medical_text":"Diagnosis:

Document Type: Discharge Summary
Discharge Summary:

•	Sex: Female
•	Service: Medicine
Allergies:
•	Nevirapine
•	Abacavir
•	Ampicillin
•	Tylenol
•	Zidovudine
Attending Physician:  Dr. Sarah Mitchell
Chief Complaint: Increased lower extremity swelling and concerns about self-care at home.
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedures:
•	Left femoral central line
•	Right internal jugular central line
•	Continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH)
History of Present Illness:
The patient is has HIV/AIDS (CD4 count of 5 as of 2023-08-23, unknown viral load) and cardiomyopathy (ejection fraction [EF] 20%) who was recently hospitalized for bibasilar pneumonia. She completed a two-week course of antibiotics (Levofloxacin and Flagyl). She presented with complaints of persistent leg swelling and weakness for two weeks. She denied shortness of breath, eating salty foods, and fever but reported consuming canned chicken noodle soup. She had received partial prescriptions after her previous discharge but did not know the names or doses of her HIV medications, identifying only Bactrim as her HIV medicine.
In the Emergency Department (ED), the patient received IV Lasix, and a femoral line was placed due to difficult venous access.

Past Medical History:
•	HIV/AIDS: History of PCP x 2, MAC, cervical dysplasia, HSV anal ulcers. Last CD4 count of 5 on 2023-08-19.
•	Cardiomyopathy: EF 20% as of 2023-12-28.
•	Renal Insufficiency: New renal insufficiency since 2023-11-18 with baseline creatinine in the mid-2s.
•	Depression
•	Asthma

Social History:
•	Divorced, lives with her 13-year-old daughter.
•	Ambulates with a walker.
•	Denies tobacco, alcohol, or drug use.
Family History:
•	Coronary Artery Disease: Mother died at age 57 from myocardial infarction.

Physical Examination on Admission:
•	Vitals: Temp 97.7°F, BP 112/68, RR 18, O2 saturation not initially checked.
•	General: Alert, quiet, pleasant, sitting in bed.
•	Cardiovascular: Tachycardia, S1S2 with S3, no murmurs.
•	Pulmonary: Clear to auscultation, decreased breath sounds at lung bases.
•	Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, non-distended.
•	Extremities: Pitting edema, femoral line in place with sanguineous drainage on the dressing.

Pertinent Labs and Imaging:
•	BNP: 64,499
•	Digoxin level: 0.8
•	Creatinine: 2.1 (slightly improved from baseline)
•	Hematocrit: 27.5%
•	Albumin: 2.2
•	CXR: Persistent bibasilar pneumonia with bilateral effusions
•	Echocardiogram: EF 20%, small-moderate pericardial effusion, global hypokinesis (2023-12-28)
Hospital Course:
Ms. Emily Carter was admitted for further management of her multiple conditions, including HIV/AIDS, cardiomyopathy, and renal insufficiency. She initially presented with concerns about increased lower extremity edema, but her physical examination revealed no significant change. She was started on IV antibiotics and transferred to the ICU after developing severe lactic acidosis believed to be secondary to her HIV medications (Zidovudine). She required continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH) for acidosis and D10 for hypoglycemia.
Despite treatment, the patient experienced multi-system organ failure, including liver failure, increased oliguria, pancreatitis, and hemolysis. After discussions with her family, the decision was made to discontinue dialysis and transition to hospice care.
Family Meeting and Transition to Hospice:
The patient's family, including her 13-year-old daughter, was informed of her prognosis. The patient expressed a desire to go to hospice, which was arranged. She was discharged on a course of antibiotics and continued medications for symptom management.
Discharge Medications:
1.	Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole 80-400 mg Tablet: Take 1 tablet daily.
2.	Sevelamer 400 mg Tablet: Take 2 tablets three times daily.
3.	Digoxin 125 mcg Tablet: Take 1 tablet every other day.
4.	Ipratropium Bromide 0.02% Solution: Nebulize every 6 hours as needed for shortness of breath.
5.	Pantoprazole 40 mg Tablet: Take 1 tablet daily.
6.	Lasix 40 mg Tablet: Take 1 tablet daily as needed for shortness of breath or painful edema.
7.	Cefpodoxime 200 mg Tablet: Take 1 tablet every 12 hours for 4 days.
8.	Azithromycin 250 mg Tablet: Take 1 tablet daily for 4 days.
Discharge Disposition: The patient was transferred to Rosewood Hospice Care.
Discharge Diagnosis:
1.	HIV/AIDS
2.	Cardiomyopathy (EF 20%)
3.	New renal insufficiency (baseline creatinine mid-2s)
4.	Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
5.	Asthma
6.	Depression
Discharge Condition: Stable
Discharge Instructions:
The patient is being transferred to hospice care, with goals of comfort and symptom management. No further labs, IVs, or fingersticks will be performed.
Follow-up: None required.
Physician: Dr. Sarah Mitchell
Facility: Rosewood Hospice Care
Date of Completion: 2024-01-18",

   "simplified_text":"
### Discharge Summary for Ms. Emily Carter

**Patient Information:**
- **Name:** Ms. Emily Carter
- **Date of Birth:** February 29, 1932
- **Age:** 92
- **Sex:** Female
- **Admission Date:** January 4, 2024
- **Discharge Date:** January 19, 2024
- **Service:** Medicine
- **Attending Physician:** Dr. Sarah Mitchell

**Reason for Hospital Stay:**
- Swelling in legs and difficulty taking care of herself at home.

**Allergies:**
- Nevirapine
- Abacavir
- Ampicillin
- Tylenol
- Zidovudine

**Procedures Done:**
- Inserted a tube in the left thigh vein
- Inserted a tube in the right neck vein
- Used a machine to help filter blood (CVVH)

"
}

{
   "task":"diseaseInformation",
   "language":"German",
   "validator_enabled":true,
   "llm_name":"gpt-4o-2024-05-13",
   "medical_text":"Chronic kidney disease (CKD), also known as chronic renal disease, is progressive loss in kidney function over a period of months or years. The symptoms of worsening kidney function are not specific, and might include feeling generally unwell and experiencing a reduced appetite. Often, chronic kidney disease is diagnosed as a result of screening of people known to be at risk of kidney problems, such as those with high blood pressure or diabetes and those with a blood relative with CKD. This disease may also be identified when it leads to one of its recognized complications, such as cardiovascular disease, anemia, pericarditis or renal osteodystrophy (the latter included in the novel term CKD-MBD). CKD is a long-term form of kidney disease; thus, it is differentiated from acute kidney disease (acute kidney injury) in that the reduction in kidney function must be present for over 3 months. CKD is an internationally recognized public health problem affecting 5–10% of the world population.",
   "user_profile":{
      "gender":"male",
      "birthday":"1994-10-24",
      "martialStatus":"single",
      "religion":"Protestant",

      ],
      "educationalBackground":"school",
      "professionalBackground":"technical",
      "languagePreferences":[
         "avoidAbstractTerms"
      ]
   }
}

5.	Pantoprazole 40 mg Tablet: Take 1 tablet daily.
6.	Lasix 40 mg Tablet: Take 1 tablet daily as needed for shortness of breath or painful edema.
7.	Cefpodoxime 200 mg Tablet: Take 1 tablet every 12 hours for 4 days.
8.	Azithromycin 250 mg Tablet: Take 1 tablet daily for 4 days.
Discharge Disposition: The patient was transferred to Rosewood Hospice Care.
Discharge Diagnosis:
1.	HIV/AIDS
2.	Cardiomyopathy (EF 20%)
3.	New renal insufficiency (baseline creatinine mid-2s)
4.	Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
5.	Asthma
6.	Depression
Discharge Condition: Stable
Discharge Instructions:
The patient is being transferred to hospice care, with goals of comfort and symptom management. No further labs, IVs, or fingersticks will be performed.

History of Present Illness:
The patient is has HIV/AIDS (CD4 count of 5 as of 2023-08-23, unknown viral load) and cardiomyopathy (ejection fraction [EF] 20%) who was recently hospitalized for bibasilar pneumonia. She completed a two-week course of antibiotics (Levofloxacin and Flagyl). She presented with complaints of persistent leg swelling and weakness for two weeks. She denied shortness of breath, eating salty foods, and fever but reported consuming canned chicken noodle soup. She had received partial prescriptions after her previous discharge but did not know the names or doses of her HIV medications, identifying only Bactrim as her HIV medicine.
In the Emergency Department (ED), the patient received IV Lasix, and a femoral line was placed due to difficult venous access.

Past Medical History:
•	HIV/AIDS: History of PCP x 2, MAC, cervical dysplasia, HSV anal ulcers. Last CD4 count of 5 on 2023-08-19.

Social History:

Family History:

Physical Examination on Admission:

Hospital Course:
Ms. Emily Carter was admitted for further management of her multiple conditions, including HIV/AIDS, cardiomyopathy, and renal insufficiency. She initially presented with concerns about increased lower extremity edema, but her physical examination revealed no significant change. She was started on IV antibiotics and transferred to the ICU after developing severe lactic acidosis believed to be secondary to her HIV medications (Zidovudine). She required continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH) for acidosis and D10 for hypoglycemia.
Despite treatment, the patient experienced multi-system organ failure, including liver failure, increased oliguria, pancreatitis, and hemolysis. After discussions with her family, the decision was made to discontinue dialysis and transition to hospice care.
Family Meeting and Transition to Hospice:
The patient's family, including her 13-year-old daughter, was informed of her prognosis. The patient expressed a desire to go to hospice, which was arranged. She was discharged on a course of antibiotics and continued medications for symptom management.
